name: Overview
main:
Yemen is facing a severe humanitarian crisis due to longstanding conflict between the government and the Houthi movement, which escalated in 2015. After President Hadi was forced to resign, an international coalition led by Saudi Arabia and the UAE began bombing Houthi-controlled areas.? As of February 2019, at least 24.1 million people in Yemen are in need of humanitarian assistance, an increase from the 22.2 million people in need reported in 2018.?

Yemen faces a severe food security emergency. Some 63,500 people were in IPC Phase 5 (Catastrophe) levels of food insecurity in December 2018 and January 2019. Moreover, approximately 5 million people were in IPC Phase 4 (Emergency), and 10.8 million people in IPC Phase 3 (Crisis). Some 19.7 million people lack access to adequate healthcare, of which 14 million are in acute need of assistance. In addition, there have been outbreaks of cholera and diphtheria.?

Widespread violations of international humanitarian law have resulted in loss of life and destruction of infrastructure. Around 3.34 million people are internally displaced.? Fighting and airstrikes limit access to humanitarian assistance.?

Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has an active presence in some of the southern governorates, as does the Yemeni branch of ISIS, although to a much lesser degree.?

For 2019, INFORM rated Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis very high, at 7.8/10. The "Hazard and exposure" category is ranked at an alarming level of 8.1/10.?
latest_developments_past: 12/03: At least 22 civilians were killed, and another 30 were injured, by airstrikes in Kushar district, Hajjah Governorate, between 9-10 March. Hajjah is currently one of the Governorates most affected by conflict in Yemen, and has the highest proportion of severely food insecure people in the country. Some 1,592,000 people (66% of the population) in Hajjah are in IPC Phases 3-5, including 19,000 people in IPC Phase 5.?
